titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Sun rose 4:26. Set 7:40. Day 15 hours 14 minutes. Not clear. I went to Boston with Charles— Met at his Office Mr Nathanl. Curtis, and completed the business, of the transfer by Caleb Curtis, James Savage, and Josiah Quincy junr. of 170 shares of the Bank of the United States, as a payment in behalf of Petty Vaughan of 20,000 dollars, by composition of the £10244:16:10 sterling recovered from the French Government, for the confiscation of certain rentes into which had been converted the proceeds of 297. barrels of Whale Oil, shipped by Moses Gill to Thomas Boylston, by a vessel called the Fair Lady, and which it was agreed between Gill and Boylston, should be on Gill’s Account—and of the remainder of the Cargo of the Fair Lady consisting of 907 Barrels of Sperm oil which was on account of Boylston— From extracts from the correspondence between Gill, and Boylston, and a stated account, in a book kept by Mr Ward N. Boylston, I made a rough estimate that the portion belonging to the Estate of Gill of the whole sum recovered from the French Government was about ten per cent of the whole— The shares were transferred at 117 dollars 75 cents a share with the dividend on, being the market price on the 22d. of June, the day upon which Mr Curtis, Mrs Boylston, and I executed the 3 copies of the Indenture of release. Mr Frothingham the agent of the Bank of the United States procured a price current of the stock on the 22d. of June which was noted 117.50 offered 118 asked. we therefore fixed the rate at 117:75— The 170 shares were then transferred to me, as administrator de bonis non of Thomas Boylston with the Will annexed, and I transferred 145 shares to John Quincy Adams, Nathaniel Curtis, and Alicia Boylston, Executors of the last Will of Ward Nicholas Boylston, reserving 25 shares in my capacity of Administrator of the Estate of Thomas Boylston to satisfy the claim of the Estate of Moses Gill— Mr Curtis took the certificate for 145 shares in the name of the Executors of Ward N. Boylston, and engaged to receive and payer over to me the dividend payable this day, for which he will receive a check from his brother; and he will also pay to him the 17 dollars 50 cents by which the 170 shares of the stock exceed the sum of 30000 dollars— I called at the Office of the Register of Probate— Neither the judge nor Register was there; but I received the copy of the Statement made by me to the judge on the 28th. of June 1830. in place of an Inventory. Copies of my account and petition of 17. June last and of the judges decree thereon, are not yet ready. but I am to call for them in three or four weeks— After some other trifling calls I returned with Charles home to dinner— Slept away the afternoon, and after seeing the Sunset, from Charles’s porch paid an Evening visit to Dr Woodward—

Morning visit from Mr and Mrs Armstrong.— He gave me several pamphlets and asked me the meaning of the word sesquipedalian, used in my second Letter to the Petitioners, in referring to the writings of Dr Johnson— I told him it was a Latin word used by Horace, in speaking of certain poets who affected pompous language, and meant words a foot and a half long. He said he found every day his deficiency in not having learnt Latin— I thought that word would puzzle some of the groundlings: but I thought also there
there were so few of them who would ever read the Letters that it was not worthwhile to leave out the word, for their sakes— Charles’s wife who came in, told Mr Armstrong that she had recognized his carriage by the arms. He laughed and said his arm with a lifted hammer were painted over his initials on his carriage to signify that he was a mechanic— He is of the mind of the Frenchman who boasted his 600 years of roture.— I went with Charles to the annual dinner party of the proprietors of Neponset Bridge at Squantum—Captain Josiah Bass, Dr Frothingham, G. W. Beale, Thomas Daniel and E. Price Greenleaf, Mr Head, Mr Lunt, Edward Miller, Mr Torrey, Mr Wayles and Augustus Whitney formed the company— The fare indifferent, and the dinner dull—but the weather fair. We went to look at the pudding stone rock with the impression upon it of shod human feet— I asked Mr Lunt whether it would not be well to administer the communion on the centurial day, the 29th. of September. He said he had thought of it and would propose it to the church— We came home between 6 and 7. and I spent the Evening with Charles and his wife, under his porch— My wife, with Mrs John, and her daughter Fanny, went into Boston this afternoon with Miss Mary E. Estelle Cutts, who leaves us, and embarked this Evening accompanied by Coll. Bomford, and Misses Mary and Georgiana Harrod in the Steamer for Portland. Miss Cutts is going immediately to visit her relations at Saco.— Our Ladies got home just before 9.— Charles had just time to get home when there came a heavy shower.

Rain, the greater part of the Night; and in showers all this morning. I intended to be industrious; but among the most ravenous absorbents of time is the reading of Letters newspapers and pamphlets by the daily mail which occupy from two to three hours almost every morning— Besides my diary and index, I was able to write this day only a part of a Letter to Joshua Leavitt and H. B. Stanton, and not to finish it. Charles and his wife with their two elder boys dined with us. Their daughter Louisa Catherine was unwell, and confined at home— Afternoon visits from Mr Bradburn of Nantucket, and Mr Francis Jackson of Boston— Mr Bradburn is to deliver an Anti-Slavery Oration to morrow in a church, in Chardon Street. I had an impression that they came to invite my attendance at their celebration, and informed them that I had declined several invitations elsewhere, and proposed to pass the day at home— We had much conversation upon the abolition of Slavery; the right of petition, the license law, and phrenology, upon all which our opinions, were very discordant; but which we discussed in perfect good humour— Dr Sewall has published my Letter to him, on his two Lectures upon phrenology, and it has brought me into collision with all the whimsicals of that school. Mr Bradburn avowed that he was a warm phrenologist, and asked me, if I had read the writings of Gall, Spurzheim and Combe— I said no, and he said my conclusions were naturally such as a person
would draw who had not thoroughly examined the subject.— I have heard and read enough in support of phrenology to be satisfied that it is fantastical, and do not think it necessary to read the 21 folio Volumes of Albertus Magnus to satisfy myself that the philosopher’s stone is to be found in the Paradise of fools— Mr Francis Jackson, is the presiding Officer of an Association for prosecuting infractions of the license law, which is raising an insurrection in the State— I asked these Gentlemen to excuse me for speaking to them without reserve, and gave them freely my opinion that it is a vain attempt to enact Laws against the strong current of public opinion— I told Mr Jackson, that he would live to see that the license law could not be carried into execution. He said there had been 60000 petitioners for the law, and only 15000 against it— I said that throughout the American Revolutionary war, there had been about 500 members of the British House of Commons for the acts which had produced it, and from 40 to 50 against them— The great difficulty of unpopular Laws is not in the enactment, but in the Execution— Alpheus Spear was here and settled with me for his last Quarter’s rent— It belated me to go up the hill till after the setting of the Sun. Campbell and Isaac Hull Adams were there and here, with Elizabeth C. Adams, and Anna Maria De Wint. Campbell and Hull sang duets. I potted a Mammoth wild garden Strawberry surrounded with red cherry-stones.
4. III:50. Thursday
Independence day. 63.

Spent at home, and only hearing in quietude all the distant din this world can keep— I visited my garden, Nursery, Seminary and Orchard, and worked in them sufficiently for the exercise of the day. I topped three of the most luxuriantly growing seedling peach trees of the present year, in the Seminary plats, and observed that some of the white, black, red, chesnut and English white Oaks, are just now putting forth new shoots, while others are stationary. Some of the walnuts are forming top buds to open next Spring as the horse chesnut has done.— The Ash, the Elm and the Maple grow without intermission; and above all the Maples from the Philadelphia seed— The growth of apple and pear seedlings is almost universally stunted by aphides or green lice gathering round the leading shoot at the top, followed by swarms of ants; while the curculio or beetle bug prowling in the darkness of Night tops the Oak and the walnut— The same or another nightly bug perforates the leaves especially of the Apricot trees, till every leaf upon the tree is reticulated and decussated with interstice betwixt the intersections like Dr Johnson’s net work— The Ash, Elm and Maple are less annoyed with insects and therefore grow more freely.— The growth of the maple is beautiful— The leading shoot like the stem of a round spire of grass, throws out at alternate right angles a pair of symmetrically indented leaves, green on the upper, and whitish blue on the under surface—the opening leaves assume a flat position, and the shoot pushes them up two or three inches, spreading all the time in size, stretching out upon a stalk, and opening another pair of leaves at right angles with it.— This process is continued through the whole Season, and the twig of the tree sometimes grows five feet in one summer. The English while Oaks are again covered with acorns; though I fear this tree like the black walnut will always be in danger
danger of being killed by our winter’s frosts.— Four of my ten transplanted seedling cherries in the Orchard are alive, and two of them have considerably grown— The large mazzard cherry tree, has scarcely born at all this year, and I found on it this day only one unripe cherry. The red cherry trees in the garden have been thoroughly stripped by the birds and by ourselves— The Strawberries have also been gathered unripe— Currants reddening. Mr Joshua Smith of Hanson called on me this morning about the Pension claim of Mrs Lucy, widow of Levi Everson— This is one of those rejected by the Commissioner of Pensions, and in answer to a recent Letter from Mr Smith, he refers him to a Letter from him the Commissioner to me ofFebruary last.— I had not this Letter at hand, and am apprehensive I left the file of Mr Edwards’s Letters to me on pension claims at Washington. I promised however to make search for it— He asked if it would be proper for Mrs Everson to petition Congress at the next Session— I said perhaps she might obtain the pension by petition; and that I would with pleasure present a petition for her— At Sunset I went up the hill to Charles’s and he and his wife came for half an hour down. Mrs John Adams was taken very sick with a bilious complaint this afternoon— And her daughter Fanny is quite unwell— There were light thunder showers and cannonading and ringing of bells all round us throughout the day
5. III:50. Friday.

Morning call from Mr Lunt, with a list of Books, which he was desirous of consulting for the composition of his centurial discourse— I had a large portion of them; but not all— Part of those I had he took with him— I shewed him also the old papers which have descended to me from uncle Norton Quincy, relating to his father, and to the mount Wollaston Estate— Some of these I had myself not duly examined; and among the rest I found an account of Guardianship of John Quincy, by Thomas Brattle dated in 1712. the year after John Quincy came of age— Thomas Brattle was the husband of Elizabeth Ting, sister to Anna Ting the wife of Thomas Shephard, and mother of John Quincy’s mother— She and Daniel Quincy had been married at the House of Thomas Brattle, that same night when Thomas Brattle’s wife so suddenly died— This Thomas Brattle the guardian was doubtless the son of the one at whose house Daniel Quincy was married— He was graduated at Cambridge in 1676. the same year with the third Thomas Shepard, and was afterwards Treasurer of Harvard College— In 1712 he must have been about 55 years of age; and was first cousin to John Quincy’s mother. I gather thus from time to time small incidents of the life of my ancestor John Quincy of whose life it would be delightful to me, to possess a circumstantial account— Had I possessed this curiosity, while my father and mother, my Uncle and Aunt Cranch, or still more while my mother’s uncle Norton Quincy lived, how much more, I might have known, of this man so eminent in his day, and the filial piety of whose daughter, at his death and at my birth gave me his name.— I must examine his papers.
Charles went to Boston, and returned home to dined wit I dined with him— Campbell and Isaac H and Elizabeth C. Adams were there. They were here this Evening— Mrs John Adams was confined to her chamber, and most of the day to her bed— At my visitation of the Seminary, I measured several of my seedling fruit trees to mark the process of their growth— Close to the Seminary gate, where I wish to raise one Apple-tree to remain, I have five seedlings, the seeds of which were sown, in the autumn of 1835 and which came up in the Spring of 1836.— One of them has a strait stem 31 inches high; but at the top of which this Spring the Aphis planted his Colony and stopped its growth— Its side leaves have curled up, and it shews no sign of increase for the present year another had made last year a stem about ten inches high— Three or four inches of which died down last winter. A side shoot came out this Season, and it is now two feet high, growing with fair promise; from which I have almost daily pinched off the aphis and the ant— The other three began the season with a promise, but have all been stunted, and will come to nothing. One seedling budded cherry is 37 inches high—
6. IV: Saturday.

I am yet unable to accomplish anything beyond keeping up the current record of my diary, and bringing up the arrears of the index, at the rate of a month in three days; and I am yet more than four years in arrear. I cannot even finish a Letter in answer to an invitation from Joshua Leavitt and H. B. Stanton to attend a great National Anti-Slavery Convention at Albany, which I began last Wednesday— I called at the Quincy-Stone bank, and made two deposits there: and at the Office of the Quincy Patriot— My second Letter to the Petitioners is not yet in the paper; but is this day promised for next Saturday— A man named Thomas Shed brought two boxes of a new invented kind of soap, which we took— Campbell, Isaac Hull and Elizabeth C. Adams with my Son Charles dined and spent the day here— Charles’s wife came in the Evening— Mrs John Adams has recovered, but her daughter Fanny is very unwell and deaf.— Showery-day. Here I begin, to be continued from day to day, till completed, a List of papers relating to the title to Mount Wollaston, and to John Quincy my ancestor its proprietor.

1. An Indenture dated 10. April 1639. between William Tynge of Boston, New-England Merchant, and William Coddington of Aquedneck in New-England, Gentleman.— A mortgage of those Lands Tenements and Hereditaments at Mount Wollaston in New-England, which the said William Tynge lately purchased of the said William Coddington— The mortgage is for the payment of eight hundred pounds of lawful money of England, in four annual instalments of 200 pounds each on the 1st. of May 1640–41–42–43.— The signature and seal of this ded, are taken off, and there is a discharge of the Mortgage endorsed upon it.
2. 1639. 26. August— William Coddington to William Cheesborough— Letter of Attorney to sell all his Lands at Mount Wollaston.

3. 1639. 16. 8th. Month— Deed Richard Wright to William Tynge, for £333:6:8 parcels of land; one of 200 Acres upland and marsh—one of 306 Acres, and one ofAcres in the great swamp near the town bounds— Acknowledged theday of April 1642 before Thomas Dudley. and Copy of the same deed.

Heard Mr Benjamin Kent in the morning from Matthew 28.9. [“]And as they went to tell his disciples, behold, Jesus met them, saying, All hail. And they came, and held him by the feet, and worshipped him.— and 17. And when they saw him they worshipped him: but some doubted.”— The text of his afternoon discourse escaped me—but it was part of a verse merely naming Heaven— There is some singularity in Mr Kent’s manner of delivery—an effort too visible at the emphatic— His morning discourse, was a dissertation and declamation, upon the fact that the two Mary’s, and the disciples worshipped Jesus upon his first appearance to them after his resurrection. The afternoon sermon was an enquiry more curious than profitable as to the locality of Heaven— Mr Kent’s health is very infirm, and his appearance in the pulpit is pale and emaciated— His mind is ingenious—inquisitive— poetical—but not generally pleasing— There was a tincture of enthusiasm in both of his Sermons of this day, which is infectious among the young clergymen from the Divinity School at Cambridge. The word worshipped in these two verses means that they kissed his feet— Mr Kent dined with us.— He is a graduate of Harvard University of 1820— In December 1827. and January 1828. I heard him 3. times at the Unitarian Church in Washington On the 1st. of Septenber 1831. I heard him deliver the ΦBK Poem at Cambridge and think I had not seen him since— He was then Colleague Pastor with Dr John Allyn at Duxbury— He has since then been compelled by ill health to leave that Church, and is now keeping a girl’s school at Roxbury; and occasionally supplying the Pulpit of the Revd. Chandler Robbins at Boston, who is gone to Europe to recover his health from a complaint of Bronchitis— After the second Service Mr E. Price Greenleaf came in, and went with me round my garden and Nursery.— I went up to Charles House at Sunset, and he and his wife came and spen the Evening here.
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued

4. 1639. 16. 8. Month.— Deed of Richard Wright to William Chesebrough for £133:6:8 currant mony of England, of 200 acres of Land, upland and marsh together at Mount Wollaston in two several parcels, one of 190 acres and the other of 10 Acres, in the great swamp near the town’s bounds, and bordering on Lands of William Tynge and others; which Lands Wright had purchased of Cheesebrough, Assignee of William Coddington.
This Deed is witnessed by John Mylam, William Tynge and John Oliver. Endorsed. Acknowledged by the within named Richard Wright the 18. of the first month 1641. Before me Jo: Winthrop
Inrowled 24 (2 mo) Anno dmni 1642
Another endorsement
Rych: Wryght’s deed to William Cheesbrough for 200 Acres Lands at Mount Wollaston 1639. and below
others are joind to it.
8. IV. Monday—

Dijah Bowen resides in Boston. He came this morning with a claim for 320 Acres of public lands in behalf of a man named Pierre Gedeon a native of St. Domingo, who in February 1815 enlisted at New-Orleans for the War in a volunteer corps called the Legion des Francs commanded by a General Humbert— The peace was then already concluded, and within a fortnight afterwards was known and ratified at Washington— Gedeon was discharged on the 15th of April within two Months after his enlistment; and without having performed any service— The Legion des Francs, never having been mustered in the Service of the United States— His certificate of discharge, declared him entitled to 320 Acres of Land, according to an Act of Congress of 10. December 1814.— But there was an endorsement upon it dated in 1828. purporting to be from a clerk in the War Department, and stating that Gedeon was not entitled to these 320 Acres of lands— This endorsement, Mr Bowen said was a cheat, not written by the Clerk whose name it bore— But he had a Letter from William Gordon, chief clerk of the bounty land Office, dated in March 1830. stating that Humberts Legion of Francs, never had been recognized as forming part of the Army of the United States, and that no public lands had been granted to any person as a member of that corps— Mr Bowen said he had been informed that other members of the corps had obtained lands in the State of Indiana— I said if it was so, there must have been a reversal of the decision of the War Department since the date of Mr Gordon’s Letter— I advised him to write again to Mr Gordon—state the information that he had received, and restate his claim. And I offered him any assistance in my power.— Campbell, Isaac H. Adams, and his Sister Elizabeth dined with us. Great crash of glass and crockery ware, by the oversetting of a modern Mahogany table with only one central leg— After dinner I took a ride with Charles through Braintree and Weymouth by the old mansions of Dr. Tufts, and of my grandfather Smith, which he had never seen, but which recall to my mind so many tender and pleasing associations— We returned by the way of the Bent’s point Bridge.
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued
5. 1640. 10: 9. Month. Deed from William Chesebrough to William Tynge—

For £127. currant mony of England—of 200 Acres of upland and marsh together purchased of Richard Wright, reserving to Chesebrough 15 Acres, and a half in two parcels already laid out, one of nine acres and the other of 6. Acres and a half.—
Witnessed by John Mylam and John Oliver.
Endorsed— Acknowledged by the within named William Chesebrough the 18th of the first Mo: 1641. Before me Jo. Winthrop.
Inrowled 24 (2 mo) 1642. Steph: Winthrop recr.
Wm Cheesbrough and others sales.
9. III:50 Tuesday.

Morning visit from Mr Loring of Hingham, who proposed a fishing party at Cohassett which I accepted but without fixing the day— I spoke of his speech in the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth last Spring, which was much distinguished. It was in favour of the Western Railroad— He also moved Resolutions remonstrating against the movements in the Senate of the United States, for a repeal of the bounty on the fisheries; and otherwise took a leading part in the House— He spoke of the abolition celebration of Independance last week at Scituate, where the Oration was delivered by W. L. Garrison and where he says my Letters to the Petitioners were roughly handled— To the Anti-Slavery Societies and Abolitionists they have given universal dissatisfaction— Mr Robert R. Stone of Kentucky, a student at the Law School at Cambridge brought me a Letter of recommendation from John White one of the Members of the House of Representatives of the United States from that State— Mr Stone first graduated at the University of Virginia; but has been eighteen Months at the Law School at Cambridge and is to be graduated there this year— But he is about returning immediately to Kentucky— After dinner, I had visits from Coll. John Trumbull and Genl. Ebenezer Mattoon, who is now blind, and 80 years of age. I recollected having once travelled with him in a Stage, from Boston to Brookfield, which I thought was in Octr. 1804. but upon recurring to my diary I found it was October 1801— We were then both in the prime of life, and I remember yet his sprightliness and activity— He said he had rode with me 22 years ago from Boston to Cambridge, but of this I had no recollection, and can find no trace in my Diary— He mentioned also having been an Elector of President and Vice-President with my father in Decr 1820. Coll. Trumbull had a cane of India bamboo which he said had belonged to John Robinson the pastor of the pilgrims from Leyden— His mother he said was a Robinson, lineally descended from the patriarch— He borrowed the cane from the Son of her eldest brother and now living at Wilkesbarre in Pennsylvania— The Coll. said he was now going to Plymouth and Barnstable in pursuit of his genealogical researches; and while here could not deny himself the pleasure of coming to see me— Charles went to Boston this morning and returned home to dine— I went up to his house at Sunset beclouded. He and his wife spent the short evening here— Thunder and Lightening Showery day.
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued.

6. 1643. 30. May. Deed of Release and Quit-claim from William Coddington, and his wife Mary Coddington, and Edward and Margaret Gibons, to Richard Wright of 600 acres of land more or less at Mount-Wollaston now Braintry
Attested by Nich. Eastone and John Coggeshall
subjoined.

Memdum That this 9th daye of the 4th. mo: 1643: Jeremy Clarke of Aquid the Agent for W Coddington, came before us at Boston aforesaid, and did there testifie upon his Oath that the present writing was sould and delivered by the said Wm Coddington, and Mary his wife, in the presence of the said M. Eastone and John Coggeshall 2 of the Magistrates of Aquidneck aforesaid. Jo. Winthrop: Govr.
Jo. Endecott— dep. Govr.
10. III:30. Wednesday
Sunrose 4:32. Set 7:38. beclouded. Day 15 hours 6 minutes.

Charles went to Cambridge as member of a Committee to examine the Sophomore Class in Greek. He returned home about 4 in the afternoon. Mr French the Schoolmaster came and invited me to a fishing party down below the light house to-morrow; but I was engaged— I lent him my plan of the City of Washington, for the use of his Scholars. Mr and Mrs Appleton were here this Evening; with Mrs John Foster of Portsmouth New Hampshire—also Charles and his wife— Mr Green sent me a proof of part of my second Letter to the Petitioners, which he revised, and he came and took it in the Evening— He said he should not be able to get the whole Letter into the next Saturday’s paper— He spoke also of a scrap from the Cincinnati Chronicle, relating to the Courtship and marriage of my father— Some truth, and some fancy— He said Augustus Whitney had received it from Mrs John Greenleaf, who wished its republication— I told him I would speak of it to Mrs Greenleaf; and return the slip to him—perhaps with some remarks— I bethought myself of writing a Lecture upon Judicial Astrology—a project—will it ever be executed?— Mr Green told me he had heard I had written a Letter to Henry Williams on the license Law.

list.head: List of Mount Wollaston papers continued.

item.p: 7. 1644. 22. August— I Allexander Wynchester have sold Wm. Tynge my houseng and lands at Brayntry at Mount Wollaston-point— 4 Acres by the house broken up, whereof there is a garden 36 Acres of upland at Mons.adjoyning the lands of Abram Harding on one syde, and Mr Mellowes Sheldron on the other side, with 4 Acres Marsh In the Neck, adjoyning to the lands of the said Wm. Tynge— All which lands contayning more or less than mentiond for thirty pounds I have sold the said Wm. Tynge, and have received from him satisfaction wittnes my hand thisof1644. I say wittnes my hand this 22th. August 1644.
Recd. the last of Octobr 1644 in.
(Endorsed) 1644. Mr Wynchesters sale of House and Lands at Brayntry.

div.p: N.B.— This paper is neither acknowledged, sealed, nor attested—nor has it any words of inheritance, to convey real estate in fee— The Deeds which appear to have constituted the Estate of William Tynge at Mount Wollaston are N. 3. from Richard Wright, and N. 5. from William Chesebrough, both however grantees from William Coddington— His Release and quit-claim, with that of Edward and Margaret Gibons— N. 6. compleats the title, and fixes the measure of all the lands conveyed at 600 Acres more or less— This of course included Germantown— The original grant was thus to William Coddington, and passed from him through his agent William Chesebrough and his assignee Richard Wright to William Tynge. The completed title dates from 1644— The land is no part of the grant to Edmund Quincy.
11— III:30. Thursday.
My birth-day— 72.

Early morning visit from the Revd. Charles W. Upham, and Mr Mack of Salem, who are going on a Summer excursion to Plymouth and upon Cape Cod— My granddaughter Mary Louisa made me a present of a silver pencil case; and Fanny of a pair of thread gloves.— I gave Mary-Louisa the first Volume of a miscellaneous collection of my Speeches Orations and other writings which have been published in pamphlets, and of which I have spare copies— I intend to give each of my Grand children a similar collection— Campbell Isaac Hull and Elizabeth C. Adams, Charles and his wife with their daughter and sons J. Q. and C. F. dined with us— Charles had been to Boston this morning— I went home with Louisa Catherine and John Q. about Sunset, and Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— The day was showery with Lightening when I first rose—heavy thunder about noon, and sharp lightening again all the Evening—
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued.

8. 1640. 13. of the 3d. mon. 1640.— Paper endorsed. Boston grant to Braintree. At a General Court of Elections held at Boston the thirteenth of the 3d. mo. 1640. The Petition of the Inhabitants of Mount Wollaston was voted and granted them to be a Town, according to the agreement with Boston, provided that if they fulfill not the Covenant made with Boston, and hereto affixed it shall be in the power of Boston to recover their due by action against the sd inhabitants or any of them. And the Town is to be called Braintree.

It was agreed with our neighbours of Mount Wollaston (viz) Wm. Chesebrough Alexander Winchester, Richard Wright James Penniman &c In the name of the rest (for whom they undertook) that they should give to Boston 4s: 6d. ye acre for 2 acres of the 7 Acres formerly granted to diverse of Boston upon expectation they should have continued still with us: and 3s. 6d ye Acre for every Acre which hath been or shall be granted to any others who are not Inhabitants of Boston, and that in consideration hereof and after the said portions of money shall be paid to the Town Treasurer, all the said Lands shall be free from any Town Rates, or Charges to Boston, and upon these Terms, and also from all Country Rates assessed with Boston, but to be rated by the Court, by itself: Provided that this order shall not extend to any more or other Lands than such as shall make payment of the said Rates so agreed upon of 4s. 6d and 3s. 6d. the Acre. And upon the former Consideration there is granted to ye Mount all the Rocky ground Lying between the fresh brook and Mr Coddington’s brook, adjoyning to Mr Haven’s farm and from the West corner of that farm to the Southmost Corner of Mr Hutchinson’s farm, to be reserved and used in Common forever, by the Inhabitants and Landholders there, together with another parcel of Rocky ground near to the Knight’s neck which was left out of the third company of Lotts, excepting all such grounds, lying among or neare the said Rocky grounds, formerly granted out in Lotts to particular persons.
12. III:30. Friday.

The Revd. William M. Cornell some time Minister of the Orthodox Church called this morning and said that he had been compelled by the state of his health to give up his profession as a Minister of the gospel, and had opened a school to prepare boys for College, and in making references, for character, it might be useful to him, to give my name, as other gentlemen of the town had authorized him to do.— I said that with regard to his peculiar qualifications as a teacher, I had not the pleasure of being sufficiently acquainted with him to speak of my own knowledge; but that to the respectability of his character, and his integrity so far as he was known to me, he might rely upon my disposition to render him any service in my power. And if called upon I would cheerfully bear testimony in his favour. Just four years ago, Mr Cornell in the heat of youthful zeal for orthodoxy wrote certain strictures upon the moral and religious character of the Inhabitants of this town which were published and roused their resentment vehemently against him—and Town Meetings were held, and a large Committee was raised, of which I was chairman, to vindicate the character of the town— We had a correspondence with Mr Cornell, and reported Resolutions declaring his aspersions false and groundless; which were adopted and published, and there it ended— Mr Cornell’s burning zeal was cooled, and his conduct has ever since been prudent and exemplary. He suffers now with a disease in the throat called Bronchitis, which is said to have become almost an epidemic among the preachers— This afternoon I made out a second account as Administrator de bonis non of Thomas Boylston, with the will annexed and endeavoured to ascertain the amount claimable by the legal representatives, of Moses Gill—but it will require considerable and cautious research: and especially prudent and righteous management.— Charles went to Cambridge as one of a Committee to examine the junior Class in Greek— He returned about 5. P.M. I spent the Evening at his house—with Mrs John Adams—Campbell and Elizabeth C. Adams.
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued

9. 1640. 10. 5th. Month— Copy, imperfect of the Deed of the School land recovered of Mr Coddington— (In the hand writing of Norton Quincy.) James Penniman, Thomas Madson, Stephen Kinsley, Gregory Baxter, Samuel Bass, and William Chesebrough deputed for the affair— It was covenanted between the Town of Braintree and Richard Wright that the said Richard Wright, shall put the Town of Braintree in full possession of one hundred andAcres of Land lying on the Neck, formerly called Coddinton’s Neck and by said Town to be held forever Viz:
N. 13. 140 Acres in 3. parcels of 40—72—and 28. Acres.

In consideration of £98:6:8. paid by the town to Richard Wright; part of £100 allowed by the Court to the town, out of the goods of Coddington attached by Wright. Delivery and Seizin to the Town acknowledged 10. 5. Mo: 1640— by Wright.
13. IV:15. Saturday— Sun rose 4:34. Set 7:36. Day 15 hours 2 minutes.

Variable weather— Transient Clouds and distant thunder— Heavy showers all around us; one as near as Squantum and only a slight sprinkling after Sunset over our own heads— I saw the Sun rise from my eastern window, and set from Charles’s porch, both clear, and the setting beautified with a great variety of forms and colouring of the surrounding clouds, worthy of the grand, majestic pencil of a Claude. I had an afternoon visit from Mr Buckingham the Editor of the Boston Courier and his Son Edgar a graduate at Harvard University of 1831. who has been settled about 4 years as a congregational Minister at Dover in New Hampshire, but has recently parted from his flock he says not from any disagreement with them, but in amity— The father resides in Cambridge, and is one of the Representatives of that Town in the State Legislature. He was for many years one of the bitterest political enemies and opponents that I ever had in the world, but I never took the slightest notice of his assaults— He finally came to me in person, offered me his friendship, and assured me that I should never more see in his paper any thing personally offensive to me— He has kept his word, and more. For without flattering me, his paper has treated me with uniform kindness— Mr and Mrs Edward Brooks with their daughter and Mrs Sidney Brooks were this afternoon at Charles’s. He and his wife spent the Evening here— I am still engaged in preparing a Statement of the claim of Moses Gill’s legal representatives upon the Estate of Thomas Boylston.
List of Mount Wollaston Papers continued.
10. 1650/51. 17. 12. Mo: Braintry Town vote; with a copy in the hand-writing of John Quincy. Braintry att a generall town meeting (17) (12) 1650

In consideration that Capt. Wilam Tynge conseants to Boston graunt dated (20) (8) [(]1647) that all such Lands of theirs within their precincts (being heretofore called and known by the name of Mount Wolliston[)] shall be acknowledged within the township of Braintry and lyable to pay all comon chardges in the town forever; when they are layd out and improved and so consents that his lands and Houses and Estates shall herein be comprehended [symbols]

It is agreed and ordered that the said William Tynge, his Lands, Farms, Housses and Estates shall not be chardged to pay any thing for or toward the purchase of the sayd grant or any privileg that shall accrew therby, and that yett notwithstanding the sayd Wm: Tynge his Heyirs and Successors forever shall enjoy to evere of his three Farms in particular all interest liberty, and privileg by the sayd graunt to the town as fully and anewally as any on inhabitant or purchaser thereof.

This is a true coppe of the Order that is recorded in the town book under my hand dat (23) (12) (1651.[)] Richard Brackett.
14. II:30 and V:5 Sunday.
Fair morning— From Noon till near Sunset, rain. Sun rose and set circumnubilated.

Heard Mr Lunt this morning from a double text. first Judges 16.28. [“]And Samson called unto the Lord, and said, O Lord God, remember me, I pray thee, and strengthen me, I pray thee, only this once, O God, that I may be at once avenged of the Philistines for my two eyes. 29. And Samson took hold of the two middle pillars upon which the house stood, and on which it was borne up, of the one with his right hand, and of the other with his left. 30. And Sampson said Let me die with the Philistines. And he bowed himself with all his might; and the house fell upon the lords, and upon all the people that were therein: so the dead which he slew at his death were more than they which he slew in his life.”

The second Luke 23.33. [“]And when they were come to the place which is called Calvary, there they crucified him, and the malefactors; one on the right hand, and the other on the left. 34 Then said Jesus, Father, forgive them; for they know not what they do.” There was a Volume of Sermons in the single consociation of these two texts— The discourse was a contrasted parallel between the lives and deaths of Sampson and of Jesus—as exemplifications of the Mosaic and of the Christian systems of Religion and Morals.— The vindictive spirit of the antient Law, and the forgiveness of injuries, the blessed Spirit of the new, are all concentrated in the last words of the two sufferers, and the mere reading of the two texts flashed with such vivid light on the minds of the auditory, that the developments of the Sermon, which could of course be nothing more than outlines, hardly sustained the expectations raised by the text.— The afternoon Sermon was from Acts 10.15. “And the voice spake unto him again the second time; What God hath cleansed, that call not thou common.”— This text also was pregnant of much more matter than was delivered in the discourse— That vision of Peter not only broke down the Wall between the Jew and Gentile—it abolished the whole ritual of the Levitical law; and there is something remarkable in the figurative character of the vision— Peter being very hungry falls into a trance, and sees a vessel laden with all sorts of animals clean and unclean—and hears a voice commanding him to kill and eat— By the Levitical Law he had forbidden to eat of any of the animals which that Law had declared unclean. Peter accordingly, hungry as he is objects to eat of the unclean animals in the visionary sheet and receives the command in the text.— Thereupon the messengers from the centurion Cornelius come to him; and he is commanded by the vision to receive them— By a corresponding vision Cornelius had been commanded to send the messengers to Peter requesting him to come and preach at Cesarea— He goes according—preaches Christ crucified to the uncircumcised Gentiles— The holy Ghost falls upon them and they are baptized— The rite of circumcision, the seal of the Covenant with Abraham is virtually abolished—all the exclusive privileges of the chosen people are superseded—and the doors of the kingdom of Heaven are opened to all mankind— It is exceedingly remarkable, and deserves a much deeper investigation than I am able to give, how Jesus in his life time apparently

disclaimed the intention to abolish the Levitical Law, expressly declaring that he came not to destroy, but to fulfil—refusing at first to heal the daughter of the Woman, of Canaan, saying that he was not sent but to the lost sheep of the House of Israel, and yet yielding at last to her importunities and to her faith— Saying also that he brought not Peace, but a sword, while the Choir of Angels at his birth had proclaimed peace on earth and good will to men. Commanding his disciples with his last words, when he last appeared before them after his resurrection, to go and teach all Nations—baptizing them in the name of the father, of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost— That all power is given unto him in Heaven and in Earth—and that he will be with them even to the end of the world— Yet leaving the questions so entirely unsettled, how far his System had abolished the Levitical Law; and how far it was retained, and whether the heathens to be received into his church without adopting the Jewish ritual or not— In the Sermon on the mount he had expressly referred to several principles in the moral part of the Law, and had enjoined upon his disciples principles more pure and benevolent— In his parables of the prodigal Son, of the good Samaritan, and of the defaulting Steward, he had undermined without abrogating the morals of the Mosaic dispensation, while he had emphatically confirmed its precepts of obedience to God and benevolence to man, and containing the whole summary of human duties— Mr Lunt’s afternoon text and Sermon opened to a very small auditory the whole of this mystery without diving very deeply into it— I read the 13th. Sermon of the 12th. Volume of Saurin, upon the last Judgment—the last of the whole collection— I began to read them on the 29th. of July 1832. and have constantly read one Sermon every Sunday, when I have been at Quincy from that day to this— I know not if there is extant a more valuable collection of Sermons; and if I have derived little or no benefit from them it has not been for want of intrinsic merit in them, but from the listlessness inattention and frailty of memory in myself— I deplore my own insufficiency, which I am too sensible increases with revolving years, and for which there is no remedy but in humble and fervent prayer to the father of Spirits that the decay of body and mind inevitable to man in the lapse of time, may be neither aggravated nor accelerated by any wilful failure, or neglect of my own.— I went at the time of the setting Sun to Charles’s House— Campbell and Isaac Hull Adams were there, and shortly afterwards came to our house, and took leave— They are going to-morrow for Albany— E. Price Greenleaf also called at Charles’s, and with him and his wife spent the remnant of the Evening with us.

I have answered a very earnest invitation of Joshua Leavitt and H. B. Stanton to attend a great National Anti-Slavery Convention to be held at Albany, on the 31st. of this month. I have declined attending on the express ground of my dissent from the Declaration of Sentiment of the American Anti-Slavery Society of 1835. and especially to the belief and affirmation “that every American citizen who retains a human being in involuntary bondage as his property is (according to Scripture) Exodus 21.16 a Man Stealer.[”] I have taken a direct issue upon that affirmation, with the American Anti-Slavery Society and all its affiliated associations— The conflict is fearful but certain as I am that this declaration is neither true nor just, I have no doubt of ultimate success in the encounter—
15. IV:10. Monday.

The Diary of yesterday, consumed too much time, and occupies too much space; and in retrieving my arrears of index I found a record of three days 26. 27. and 28 September 1835. which I had forgotten, and thought I had made no record of them at all. I had even made that entry yesterday in my index, and was now obliged to deface the book by erasing it, and making the proper entry.— There came this afternoon a man by the name of Samuel Goodhue, a Soldier of the Revolution, 74 years of age, now residing in Boston, who said he had heretofore entertained a strong desire to see and talk with my father, but had been disappointed— That he had only once seen me in company with Mr Armstrong when I delivered the Eulogy on James Madison— But he had long wished to converse with me, and to ask sundry questions, a paper of which he had in his pocket.— He said he had been a member of the Common Council, with my dear departed Son George, but was not a member of that body now. I listened to his questions and answered them as well as I could— He kept throughout for at least two hours the style of interrogation, affirming nothing himself, but disclosing clearly enough his own opinions by the character of his enquiries— He is an ardent patriot of our revolution, and now a whig abolitionist head over ears— He abhors Andrew Jackson, for his Bank war, and his removals from Office— He thinks slaveholding a crime, which ought to be abolished though it should cost the dissolution of the Union; and he thinks as it was wrong in the representatives of the free States to stipulate for the delivery up of fugitive Slaves, a bad promise is better broken than kept, and that we ought to consider that pledge in the Constitution null and void— Here is the Roman Catholic principle that faith is not to be kept with heretics, in all its glory. Mr Goodhue is sincere and honest in these opinions, and to warrant his opinion that a breach of faith with Slaveholders is an obligation of duty he instanced the case of St. Paul, who upon his conversion at Damascus, broke his promise to the high priest, to bring all the Christians he could find, in bonds to Jerusalem.— I told him the conversion of St. Paul was by a miracle—a special command from Heaven—and until we should receive a like command, it would be best for us to keep our faith— He was not satisfied with this reasoning, and insisted still on the enquiry whether a wrongful promise were not better broken than performed. He finally asked me for copies of several of my publications for which he offered to pay. but I gave him copies of my Letter to the inhabitants of the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts of 13. August 1838. of my three Letters to the Petitioners at the last Session of Congress, of the Eulogy upon La Fayette— Of the Oration at Newbury Port, and of the jubilee of the Constitution— And he gave me a printed pamphlet Biography of the family of Goodhue at Ipswich in 1636. and Genealogy to 1833; together with an Address, by Deacon Samuel Goodhue to his Descendants—and left with me a manuscript of his own composition to be returned to him— Charles with his two elder boys dined with us. His wife with Mary and her daughter Fanny went to Boston to consult the doctress Miss Hunt about Fanny’s health— They returned this Evening— Charles here.
16. IV. Tuesday—

There has been I believe for weeks not a single day without rain; and hitherto very few warm days, scarcely one warm night— My observations of my seedling plants are barren and unfruitful, and yet constitute some of the harmless pleasures of my life— My warfare with insects is like that of Uncle Sam with the Seminole Indians— The Aphis and the Ant tip the leading shoot of all my Apple and Pear-trees, though I stain my fingers and thumb with a saffron colour in pinching them off— I found this morning rolled up in two leaves at the top of the leading shoot of a pear seedling in the Seminary a nest of palmer worms just hatched not bigger than emmets, but which in ten days would have been each an inch long, and would have spread their web over the whole tree— The creeping red thread of the wild strawberry from the Hill, transplanted on the 14th. of last month to the Seminary plat 8 first appeared yesterday— The plant lives.— One of the stunted apple-seedlings next the seminary gate shews a new plumelet— So does the apple-seedling fronting my chamber window, and East of the Old Horse Chesnut— Kirk and Thomas mowed the Oats in the Orchard; but I directed them to leave a patch to go to seed— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— He brought me a pamphlet Address of William Gaston to two literary Societies at Chapel Hill, North-Carolina 20 June 1832. sent me by a Student named Francis Marion Pearson with a request to me to send him in return my Discourse at New-York. And a packet containing two copies of an English pamphlet, entitled Negro Apprenticeship in the British Colonies— And one volume, entitled the African Slave trade by Thomas Fowell Buxton Esqr. addressed to me in manuscript on a blank page fronting the title—“from T. F. Buxton March 31st. 1839.[”]— There was no Letter with the packet, and the outside cover was directed to the care of James G. Birney New-York— I went up to Charles’s porch at Sunset— He had been to Boston, and returned home to dine. He and his wife passed the Evening— My Diary, arrears of index and Statement concerning the Gill claim on the Administration of Thomas Boylston’s Estate occupied the day.
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued—
11. 1652 8. 1. Paper endorsed Comonages and privileges for the farmes at Brantrey. Brantry at the townsmens meting the (8) (1) (52)

In consideration of Capt: Wm Tynge his interest with Boston men, in all the lands of theirs within their precincts, whereof they have made a grant to this town dated 20 (8) 1647. which was delivered to remain in his hands til he was satisfied for yelding his 5 farmes to be therein comprehended and in consideration of his consenting thereunto, and delivering them up the sayd grant, it is agreed and ordered that the sayd Wm Tynge his heirs and Successors forever shall freely injoy, to every of his three farmes in particular all lybertys and privileges by the grant to the town as fully and entirely as any one inhabitant or party purchaser thereof, and shall also injoy all other privileges which the town in any wise that doth or may pertain unto the town. and it is also agreed and ordered that no way for swyne shall be required through the grounds of the sayd Wm Tynge, but such drift way as Gorg Spear hath of late in part or whole layd out for drift of Cattle, nor no way for Carts &c but the sayd drift way, when it is made
convenant for the passage thereon, by the judgment of 4 men indifferently chosen by both parties— Witnes the hands of the townsmen this meeting—
Samuell Bass, Martin Sanders, Stephen Kinsley, James Peniman, William Allis—
Copy of the first part of this paper, in the hand-writing of John Quincy.
17. IV. Wednesday.

Finished reading with my two Granddaughters the Old Testament which we began on the 30th. of November last; and we read the first chapter of Matthew— This is the third time of reading it with Mary-Louisa and the second with Fanny— We read without commenting and without explaining. The Roman Catholics forbid the reading of the Bible not only to children, but to all others unless licensed by a priest— Protestants claim the right of reading it without license— But many Parents are scrupulous about reading or suffering their children to read the whole, but I make mine read it all; for I have observed that children to whom certain parts are interdicted are always the most familiar with them— But often as I have read the Bible through, and anxious as I have been to understand it, there are numberless passages especially of the prophets, which are and ever will remain to me perfectly unintelligible. There is one source of knowledge which I have not sufficiently explored—and that is a strict observance of the Chronology of the prophets, comparing each prophesy, with the narratives in the Books of the kings, and of the Chronicles of the several times when they were written— Of the greater prophets too it is to be observed that there is no unity of subject or of composition in the book that bears only one name— Thus the prophesies of Isaiah embrace a period of 62 years, and were delivered at different times during the reigns of four successive kings of Judah. The recorded prophesies commence with Isaiah, 760 years before Christ and finish with Malachi 397 years before Christ. Some of the smaller prophets seem to have preceded Isaiah, and that of Jonah against Nineveh is marked as one hundred years earlier— Most of the prophesies relate to the Babylonian captivity and to the rebuilding of the Temple— The Apocryphal books imperfectly fill up the interval, between the close of the prophesies, and the birth of Jesus.

Charles and his family dined with us. I finished my draught of a Statement to be laid before the judge of probate at Boston, concerning the Gill portion of the monies recovered from the French Government and Petty Vaughan, in the Administration of Thomas Boylston’s Estate— Among the Letters this day received was one from Christopher Hughes, at London dated 9. June 1839. with enclosed Letters from the Duke of Sussex to him, and from the Astronomer Royal George B. Airy, to the Duke of Sussex and to Hughes relating to the enquiries, concerning the royal astronomical observatory at Greenwich— Mr Airy promises to answer these enquiries in a Letter directed to myself.— I ought to pursue these enquiries further; though I am under great discouragement of accomplishing any useful purpose by the Smithsonian fund— Yet let it not fail by any despondency or neglect of mine.
18. IV. Thursday.

I went to Boston with Charles and called first at the probate Office— The judge was not there nor in town— The Register Mr. Oliver W. B. Peabody gave me a copy of my account as administrator of T. Boylston which I settled on the 17th. of June— I made the statement concerning the Gill claim which I had drawn up in writing. Mr Peabody recurred to the 70th. chapter of the revised Code of Massachusetts, Sections 32 and 33. by which he thought the judge might decree the balance due to the Estate of Gill to be placed in a savings Bank or in Stocks bearing interest in the name of the judge to be paid to any just claimant who may hereafter appear.— Mr Nathaniel Curtis met me at Charles’s Office— I read my statement to him and desired him to consult Mrs Boylston concerning it— He had and shewed me the note of the last Moses Gill to Mrs Boylston, given in January 1829. upon interest, and the two Bonds given by Ward N. Boylston first to Henry Prentiss in December 1804. and afterwards in 1822 to John Lane Boylston for an annuity of 520 dollars a year for life to Moses Gill; which was paid until his Death, about the 1st of March 1832— I requested Mr Curtis to examine the papers of Thomas and of Ward Nicholas Boylston, for the account of Sales by Homberg and Homberg at Havre in 1791. of the Fair Lady’s Cargo; a voucher necessary to fix with certainty the proportion of Gill’s interest in it, to the whole—and also for the vouchers of the award of the Commissioners against the French Government on the whole claim— We considered the question of taking out or causing to be taken out Administration de bonis non of Governor Gill, and administration upon the estate of the last Moses Gill, which Mrs Boylston might do as a creditor—and Mr Curtis thought my Son might take out both Letters of Administration— But as this might involve him in all the concerns both of the Lieutt. Governor and of his nephew, I said I could not recommend it— We left this matter for future consultation. I called at the Merchants Bank and received 583 dollars in specie for the Treasury Notes which I have held from the 6th. of July last year on interest. At 1/2 past 12 I attended a meeting of the Overseers of Harvard University at the Council chamber— Neither President Quincy nor Governor Everett was present— A Letter from the President apologized for his absence, from the necessity of his being present at the same hour, at the valedictory oration and ceremonies at the departure of the Senior Class from the University— Francis C Gray, as the Senior (only) member of the Council present, presided at the Meeting— Its object was to propose conferring the degrees of Doctor of Laws, upon judge John M’Lean, and upon James Grahame the Scottish Historian of the United States—and of Doctor of Divinity upon Francis William Pitt Greenwood, Orville Dewey, and George Rapall Noyes— I made some observations on the Doctorate of Law proposed to be conferred upon James Grahame and Mr Ezra Stiles Gannett and the Attorney General of the Commonwealth James Trecothick Austin, remarked upon the selection of Doctors of Divinity all from the Unitarian Denomination— Dr. Francis Parkman, and Mr John Welles also made some observations, and after a short discussion, the Doctorates were referred to a Committee
Committee of three Members nominated by the Chairman to report at the adjourned Meeting on Thursday, the 22d. of August at 1/2 past 12. and at the same place— The meeting was adjourned about a quarter past 1.— I asked Mr Gray to administer the Oath to me as a Justice of Peace throughout the Commonwealth under a new Commission, the former having expired on the 24th. of May last— But Mr Gray said there must be two Councillors to administer the Oath, though it may be done by the Governor or Lieutt. Governor alone— I returned with Charles home to dinner, and went up the hill for the setting of the Sun from his porch. He and his wife spent the Evening with us.
19. IV. Friday. Sun rose 4.39 beclouded— Set 7.32 clear— Day 14 hours 53 minutes.

This was a day which ought to have been usefully occupied, for it was without interruption of visitors, of high summer temperature— Fahrenheit in my chamber at 80. but with a refreshing breeze and evening soft and balmy; but with the exception of Diary and Index, the day was wasted— I wrote not so much as a Letter and only read Charles’s article in the North American Review upon Matthew L Davis’s Memoirs, correspondence and Journal of Aaron Burr— An excellent Article which in all the newspapers which notice it with commendation is ascribed to Dr Palfrey, the present Editor of the Review. The work and the man, are thoroughly scrutinized in this review, upon the great standard of moral principle, and Burr is shown as he was, one of the worst men, who ever rose to distinction in this Country— The occasion of my great loss of time this day was the search for my Diary at the close of the year 1835. the years 1836 and 1837— In these there are intervals without record and which can never be filled up. I wish there were more reason to regret the discontinuous character of the notation of my declining years— The search for papers leads from one subject to another, and I am always obliged to close it abruptly. But it took three hours of this day— Charles and his wife went to Boston and dined with Edward Brooks. Elizabeth C. Adams was here, and rode with Mary and the children to see again the Penobscot Indians, but they were gone; and in the Evening, with my wife they made a neigbourly call at Mr Beale’s— His eldest daughter Anne is lame, with an unknown disease. My visits to my plants are fruitless— Most of them are smothered with weeds—

20. III:45. Saturday.

Sun rose 4:40. Set beclouded 7:32. day 14 hours 52 minutes— Another day chiefly consumed in examining the old papers of Coll. John Quincy and his Son Norton; and I found among them several papers of Mrs Anna Shepard, and the inventory of the Estate of William Tynge— Also sundry papers relating to the invitation to Benjamin Stevens to settle here as a Minister in 1744 after the death of Mr Hancock and to the Settlement of Lemuel Bryant in 1745. Several papers also concerning the controversy with Boston about the town lands— But considering that Coll. John Quincy was for many years the Representative of the town of Braintree in the General Court, several years Speaker of the House, and afterwards several years a member of the Council it is wonderful how scanty and meagre the list of papers is which he left— No correspondence— Not one single Letter of his of his father or mother— There are some papers relating to Mills at Charlestown bought by Thomas Shepard, and receipts for legacies bequeathed by him, given to his widow, and Executrix.— Among the papers herein before minuted there was with N 2. a copy of the paper of which I have now found the original, which so far as I can decypher it is as follows.
