div.p: The former part of this day was the most intensely warm that we have had this Season. Soon afternoon there came on a heavy thunder gust, and the remainder of the day was showery, and sultry.
21. IV. Sunday.
Heavy Shower as the Sun rose, and Showery day.

Heard Dr Frothingham this morning from Ezekiel 47:12—“and the fruit thereof shall be for meat, and the leaf thereof for medicine.”— This verse is a part of that mysterious vision of the prophet Ezekiel, the narrative of which begins at the 40th. chapter of his book and continues to the end— The man with the measuring read and the line of flax in his hand— The City of the New Jerusalem, and its re-edified Temple, for the consideration of which the reading of the 21st. and 22d. chapters of Revelation— They relate to the same New Jerusalem— The trees mentioned in this 12th. verse of the 47th. chapter, are fed with waters flowing from the sanctuary.— In Revelation 22.2 it is called the tree of life, and it is said that the leaves of the tree were for the healing of the Nations— This is all allegorical imagery— The tree, whose fruit is meat, and whose leaves are medicine is the Bible and Dr Frothingham gave an admirable exposition of its character as furnishing the nourishment to sustain life, and the medicine to heal disease— He commented upon its unity of purpose from the first verse of Genesis to the last chapter of Revelation—upon th all comprehensive nature of its subject to the condition and welfare of man in this world, and the next—upon the long extent of time over, which it ranges—the number and variety of the writers by whom it was composed: its adaptation to the wants and its tendence to elevate the nature, and to promote the happiness of mankind— All this was discussed with eloquence such as I have seldom heard— The Doctors afternoon text was from Deuteronomy 34.8. [“]So the days of weeping and mourning for Moses were ended”— A field vastly narrower than that of the morning—but it commenced with a magnificent panegyric upon the character of Moses; and discoursed upon the duties of weeping and of mourning—for a time and then of ceasing to mourn— Dr Frothingham and his Son Thomas and Charles dined with us, and Mr Degrand who remained with us till the dusk of Evening.— This morning before meeting the Revd. John Bovee Dodd called to see me. He said he was to preach three times this day at the Universalist Church and would leave town to-morrow morning, perhaps not to come again. He said that Matthias
Matthias J. Bovee who was a member of the 24th. Congress from the State of New-York was his brother, and Benedict Arnold also heretofore a member of Congress was his brother in Law— I lost my usual reading, and a part of my necessary writing this day.
22. IV. Monday.

Visit before breakfast this morning from Mr Pierpont of Boston, with a young man from Hartford Connecticut by the name of Morgan— They came to invite me to deliver the introductory Lecture to a course intended to be given next winter by an association of young men in that city formed about one year ago, and who Mr Morgan said possess already a library of 8000 volumes— Mr Pierpont said that in the general movement to mental cultivation which had for several lears past; Connecticut, heretofore distinguished for her intelligence had fallen in arrear of the Spirit of the age, and this was a very commendable effort of the young men of Hartford to redeem their lost ground— Their wish was that on my way to Washington next Winter I should take the occasion to deliver this introductory Lecture at Hartford— I declined with the same grateful sense of the kindness implied by the invitation, and upon the same general principle that as it would be utterly impossible for me to comply with one half the invitations to similar services which I receive, I find myself under the necessity of declining them all— I observed that I had made an exception for the Discourse recently delivered at New-York, because the occasion, was of so peculiar a character, and I was under so great personal obligations to the Society, of which I had been more than 25 years an honorary member, and having already declined two or three invitations to discourse before them, I had thought it a peremptory duty— I returned to Mr Pierpont the volume of Noyes’s version of the Book of Job which I have had four or five years— He told me that the new practice of Lyceum Lecturing had already put down two theatres in Boston, and he hoped would shortly put down, all the rest. The Lectures furnished a substitute for theatrical entertainments— They were constantly and fully attended, and the theatres were deserted— President Quincy, also paid me a morning visit, and spoke of the proceedings at the meeting of the board of Overseers last Thursday— I asked him when his History of the University would be published, but he could not give a decisive answer— He said the first volume was printed and stereotyped and part of the second— He had hoped the publication would be ready before commencement; but now believed that would be impossible— I told him I wanted to see the first Volume for the account of the Presidency of Leonard Hoar, the brother of Joanna Hoar Edmund Quincy’s first wife and mother of Daniel Quincy— He said that Hoar had been very ill used, and ousted from his Office by the intrigues of Urian Oakes his successor— Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us and Charles spent the Evening here— There was distant thunder and lightening and heavy showers of rain which began about noon, and continued with occasional intermissions the whole day and Evening. I received a pamphlet review (by James T. Austin) of Dr Channing’s Letter to Jonathan Phillips on Slavery— I had sent last week a copy of my New-York Discourse, to Mr Austin— This was the reciprocation of civility
23. IV:30. Tuesday

Showery day and a beclouded Sun at the rising and setting. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. Mr Lunt called upon me to borrow several volumes of the transactions of the Massachusetts Historical Society, and the old volume of the Braintree town records which I had mentioned to him, but which had been some time missing— I found it in one of my Chests of the farm house library, and Mr Lunt borrowed them all. In the afternoon E. Price Greenleaf was here—returned the French Botta, and borrowed the remaining Volumes of Adelung’s German Dictionary.— Mr Greenleaf went with me round my garden Nursery and Seminary; but he thought the time for budding even of Apple trees has not yet come— He says that the walnuts will not take buds or grafts from each other— I wrote a short Letter to M. A. Giusta enclosing a check on the Bank of Washington, for two years interest of my note to him of 1000 dollars—and another to David Crocker Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements of the Inhabitants of Barnstable inviting my attendance at their proposed celebration of the second centurial anniversary of the incorporation of that town: on the 3d. of next September; which I respectfully decline— And this I am ashamed to say was not all the labour, but all the performance of the day— Dr Frothingham has sent me the 4th. Volume of Maclaine’s Mosheim, in which I read part of the chapter of History of the Anabaptists or Mennonites— And I read some pages of Mr Buxton’s book which he has sent me on the African Slave-trade— The cruelties of that trade are heart-sickening— So are the details of Theodore D. Weld’s book—American Slavery as it is— The stomach heaves at the perusal of the numberless cases of human suffering inflicted by human hands.— I went to see the setting of the Sun, from the Porch of Charles’s house, and he and his wife spent the Evening with us.
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued.
14. 1661. 28. March Indenture on Parchment, much defaced.

Partition between Thomas Brattle and Elizabeth his wife, Thomas Shepard and Anna his wife— Bethia Ting, and Mercy Ting of the Estate of William Ting deceased— In this distribution of William Ting’s Estate, the House and Farm at Mount Wollaston, was assigned to and taken by Thomas Shepard, in the right of his wife Anna, second daughter of William Ting— Elizabeth Brattle was his eldest daughter— From this Instrument it appears that William Ting had left by Will, all his property to his four daughters in common, and that they had all administered upon his Estate— On the back of the parchments is endorsed This indenture was acknowledged by all the parties therein concerned according to Law this 28. March 1661. before me Humphrey Atherton

Anna Shepard, survived her husband who died 7 June 1685 and her daughter Anna (who was married first to Daniel Quincy, and secondly to the Revd. Moses Fiske) and finally by her Will dated 13. May 1709 gave the Estate at Mount Wollaston to her daughter’s Son John Quincy.
24. III:50. Wednesday—

Beclouded day with occasional Sunshine and no rain. I had morning visits from Mr John M. Niles, late a Senator from the State of Connecticut, and Mr Graham H. Chapin, who was a member of the House of Representatives of the United States in the 24th. Congress, both partizans of the present administration of the general Government— Chapin moderate—Niles of the most violent. After failing of re-election to the Senate he was the democratic government candidate for the Office of Governor of the State, and lost also that election. Mr Edward Cruft also with his second daughter Anna was also here.— Mrs Cruft is at Westborough— Cruft has prospered as a merchant in Boston, and prosperity and the ill health of his wife have unsettled them— They lead a rambling life. He, within the last five years has been twice to Europe, Steam-boating and railroading in England France, Holland, Germany and Russia; and now he and Mrs Cruft have been roaming about this country in like manner— He is very much soured in his politics, and has become a Jackson and Van Buren Democrat, ashamed to avow him such and angry at being thought so— His eldest Son Edward a lawyer in Boston, is a regular member of the party, and rising to distinction in it— Charles his wife and children dined with us, and without the children—they were here this Evening. I received a Letter from Joseph Blunt of New-York, with enquiries concerning the claimants to the Estate of John Stokes who died some forty years ago in North-Carolina; and about which I have already had so many applications— I answered the Letter as well as I was able from memory— Blunt says that the demand for the Jubilee of the Constitution in New-York’s neighbourhood is unprecedented and still continues—and that they have already sold 8000 copies— There is no such demand for it here. A Puff from one or two Newspapers on one side, and a cuff from the
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued

15. 1665. 10. August— Indian Deed of Wampatuck, alias Josiah Sagamore of the Massathusetts in New-England, to Samuel Basse Thomas Faxon, Francis Eliot, William Needham, William Savil, Henry Neale, Richard Thayer and Christopher Webb, all of Braintry in the County of Suffolk in New England, in the behalfe of the Inhabitants of the town of Braintry aforesaid with themselves, for £21:10. of all the Lands in Braintry, bounde on the North by Dorchester, East by the Sea, South and west by Weymouth, excepting the farms of Wilson, Coddington, Hough’s Neck and Quinsey which they had purchased of his predecessors, and which he confirms. This Deed is executed by Wampatuck, son of Chickatabut, and six of his wise men—with livery of seisin by turfe and twigge, witnessed by Roger Billing Benjamin Tompson and three Indians. An imperfect copy of this Deed is printed in George Whitney’s History of Quincy, p. 24. The date is 16 years before Penn’s Charter of Pennsylvania existed.
25. IV. Thursday

I went in to Boston with Mary, her daughter Fanny, and Elizabeth C. Adams— Call at Edward Cruft’s. He was not at home but I left a copy of the Commerce and Navigation Documents of 1838. for which he had asked me yesterday—and of which I had first received several copies, this morning—also a copy of my Discourse at New-York— I afterwards saw Mr Cruft, and he asked me to send a copy of the Commerce and Navigation Document, to his Son William Smith Cruft at New-York, which I promised— I stopd at the shop of J. G. L. Libbey working jeweller in Washington Street opposite the West end of Milk Street to purchase a key for my Chronometer, that which French sent with it being wholly of gold has in the daily use of 13 years worn out. I found no key to suit me, all the watch-keys of the present fashion being of tasteless and fantastical forms. Mr Libbey finally proposed to me to insert a steel pipe into my own key, which he did for a quarter of a dollar, and I have now a key which has every appearance of long outlasting myself— I went to the Merchants insurance company office in search of Mr Nathaniel Curtis but did not find him— Then to the probate office, where I saw the Register Mr Peabody, and the judge Mr Willard Phillips, and had much conversation with them on the proceedings necessary for me, to be discharged from responsibility as Administrator of Thomas Boylston, for the Gill claim on the 237. Casks of Whale Oil shipped in the Fair Lady in 1791.— The judge appeared to be undoubting that there must be an Administration, on the Estates of both the Moses Gills— But my course must be to present a written statement, and an Account. I made a search in the old Records for a Will of William Ting, but found none— There was an inventory of his Estate presented by his brother Edward Ting in 1653—not either as Executor or Administrator. It would seem that there was no Will; and that William Ting died in a house other than his own— The Indenture of partition dated in 1661. says that the four Sisters had by will given, and had taken Administration, of the whole Estate, and had divided it between them— There was probably a will; but it had not been legally authenticated— I was detained so long at the Probate Office, that the Meeting of the Historical Society was over before I reached their apartment— I left a copy of my Historical Discourse delivered at New-York; took the seven Volumes which have been published of the third Series of the Transactions of the Society; and franked a Diploma of honorary member of the Society to Daniel D. Barnard of Albany, whom I had nominated at the meeting in May—and who had been elected, at the Meeting in June, when I was absent, unwell— The President Thomas L. Winthrop invited me to dine with him, but I had promised to return to dine with Charles at Quincy. I found my companions at Mrs Frothingham’s— Her husband was gone to New-York. I left with her a copy of my Discourse for Harriet Welsh, and we returned to Quincy just in time at 1/2 past two to dine at Charles’s with Mr P. C. Brooks and Mr and Mrs. Sidney Brooks After dinner we rode to Willard’s granite quarry and saw several of the fluted columns and chapiters in preparation for the Exchange at New-York. Mr and Mrs S. Brooks left us about Sunset— Mr P. C. Brooks stays over the Night. Our Ladies passed the Evening at Charles’s.
26. IV. Friday.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— This was the forty-second anniversary of my wedding day— A day ever to be gratefully remembered by me. Mr Brooks was here after breakfast and returned to Boston homeward— I could not prevail upon him to stay and dine with us. He went round my garden, nursery and seminary. and saw my seedling trees— He discovered one large white plum on a tree near the summer house cellar in the garden, which I have been five or six years cherishing as a cherry tree. He says that not one of the English white Oak Acorns which he sowed last autumn has come up— I have only two— I continue myself to vegetate and to do nothing; and in tracing the causes of my imbecility find two which consume more of my time than all the rest put together. 1. The hours wasted in visiting my seedling plants—and 2. The daily mail of Newspapers Letters and pamphlets— Thus at least two hours of this day were absorbed in reading an Address touching the Influence and progress of Literature and the Sciences delivered before the Philomathean Society of the Indiana University at the annual commencement 1738. by Robert Dale Owen, one of the Trustees of the University—a Son of Robert Owen of Lanark; and a man whom I have for years been accustomed to consider as a nuisance to human Society— I know not who has sent me this Address, which is full of excellent sentiments and is altogether unexceptionable and a Letter from Mr George B. Airy, Astronomer Royal with answers to my enquiries sent by Christopher Hughes— Highly valuable, if I only knew what use to make of them— I have also an answer to write to Gerrit Smith, in the composition of which I must pause and pause and pause again— I began it but made little progress— Mary and her daughter Fanny, dined at Mrs T. B. Adams— Charles’s wife went in the Evening— He was here.
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued
16. 1662. 5. April. Letter from Leonard Hoar to Edmund Quinsey, dated Hull

Leonard Hoar was graduated at Harvard College in 1650. Edmund Quinsey born in 1628. was on the 26th. of July 1648 married to Joanna sister of Leonard Hoar, born in 1625 and by her had four Sons and eight daughters. She died 16 May 1680. and her grave stone yet stands in the Quincy graveyard— Daniel Quinsey their eldest Son was born 12. Septr. 1650. He was in his 12th. year when this Letter was written, from which it appears that his father had then placed him for Education with his Uncle John Hull— In 1652 John Hull was appointed Master of the Mint, and coined the New-England pine tree shillings six pence and three pence pieces. The Letter mentions the writers having just received information of the death of the common mother Joanna Hoar, who died in December 1661. and that Daniel Quinsey had been dangerously ill but had recovered. He speaks of Cousin Hull as being at that time at London— He had married a Sister+ of Edmund Quinsey— Hoar afterwards in 1672 came again to New-England, and was President of Harvard College about 2 years— A remarkable part of this Letter is that it tells of the difficulties which Hoar met with in efforts to procure Servants to send out to Mr Quinsey, and to brother Flint+ Judith—died 22 June 1695.
27. IV Saturday.

Mr and Mrs Barrell with Harriet Welsh, paid us a morning visit from Boston— Miss Welsh urges me exceedingly to work upon the biography of my father—she also shewed me a Letter from my mother written in 1818. declining the publication of a collection of her Letters.— I made an effort to do something this day, but did not even finish my Letter in answer to Gerrit Smith— I visited my seedling plants— The young elm, transplanted to the orchard, and the shoot severed from the old stump on the 18th. of May, are both alive, and have put forth leaves— So have six of the ten seedling mazzard cherries and one wild cherry which I transplanted on the 20th of May— But the Apple-seedlings, transplanted by Kirke before I came home are very unpromising— There must be an art of producing leading shoots to fruit trees, of which I have only a conception— The wild Strawberry which I brought over from the Hill on the 14th. of June lives and is putting out runners— Three of the Medford Baldwin Apple trees set out in the garden in October 1830. bear their first fruit— My only excursion beyond my garden was to Charles’s porch at Sunsetting, beclouded. He and his wife passed the Evening here
List of Mount Wollaston papers continued.
17. 1669. 1. December.— Plan of the Mount Wollaston farm, then belonging to Mr Thomas Shepard—on Parchment very indifferently executed. See this Diary of 20. June 1839.

18. 1676. 15. January. Boston Letter from John Hull to Daniel Quinsey then in London—26 years of age and six years before his marriage— He could not have been long in England, for the year before, in 1675 he had been admitted a member of the antient and honourable Artillery company. It begins however by referring to a preceding Letter of 20. October 1675. in which he had announced to Daniel Quinsey the death of two of his Sisters. This Letter does not name them, but announces the death of John Reyner, minister at Dover, New Hampshire, recently married to Daniel Quinsey’s sister Judith— She herself died at her fathers house at Braintree on the 3d. of March 1680. at the age of 25 little more than two months before her mother, close at the side of whose gravestone in the Quincy cemetery stands hers.— This Letter states that Mr Reyner had made a will and appointed Edmund Quinsey his Executor, and gave him land in England at a place called Gildreson, for and in behalf of Judith, and also a considerable part of his Estate here; but Edmund Quinsey declined acting as Executor— It would seem as if Daniel Quinsey had gone to England to purchase arms, and other iron ware; much of the Letter relating to that speculation— He knows not how to advise Daniel, as to the time of his coming home, but hopes the Lord will direct him— He mentions a great fire at the North end, which on the 27th. of November 1675. had consumed a considerable part of the town, and concludes with edifying religious sentiments and pious consolations.
28. III.50. Sunday.

Heard Mr Lunt this morning from Hebrews 4:3. [“]For we which have believed do enter into rest.” The Discourse was an exposition and Commentary upon the import of the word rest in this text, in which rest he said there was more of Heaven, than in any other word in human language— The conclusion was that rest could be obtained by the practice of religion and of beneficence.— The text was susceptible of large disquisition upon the influence of belief, in the acquisition of rest— But upon this Mr Lunt scarcely touched. It is certain that Christ and his Apostles dwell much upon the irresistible power of belief, which is the foundation of Christian Faith— I would wish to see reconciled with each other many passages in the New Testament, which seem to have different bearings on this principle of belief— In some places Christ performs miracles to reward the belief of those who ask them— In others to convince those who disbelieve— In one place it is said that he could not perform many mighty works, because of their unbelief In another he says that a wicked and adulterous generation ask for a sign, but no sign shall be given them, but that of the prophet Jonas; meaning thereby his own resurrection. The difficulty to be solved is why the evidence of miracles should be given to those who already believe, and denied to those who need help to their unbelief. When John the precursor baptized Jesus, the Spirit of God descended and lighted upon him in the likeness of a dove and a voice from heaven was heard, saying this is my beloved son in whom I am well pleased— This was seen and heard by John the Baptist who even before he performed his function knew that Jesus was the Christ— And yet when he was cast into prison—he sent into prison by Herod, he sent his disciples to Jesus to enquire whether he was the true Messiah, or whether they were to wait for another— Jesus without answering the question directly, tells the disciples of John, to inform him of the miracles he had performed, and adds blessed are they who shall not be offended in me— The miracles were the evidence of the Mission, and yet they did not produce conviction upon great multitudes who witnessed them. Mr Lunts afternoon text was John 6:38. [“]For I came down from Heaven, not to do mine own will, but the will of him that sent me.” The deep humility of this declaration; the conformity to it of the whole career of Christ upon Earth, and the lesson of duty taught to all the disciples of Christ both by the precept and the example were set forth in the discourse with great animation and impressive eloquence.— Having read through the Sermons of Saurin, I began this day with a volume of Sermons by Nathan Parker D.D. late Pastor of the South Church and Parish at Portsmouth New-Hampshire published after his death by a Committee of the Parish—with a Memoir of the author by Henry Ware junr. Professor of Pulpit Eloquence and the pastoral care in Harvard University— There are 40. Sermons the first of which I read; entitled “Man accountable to God alone in matters of Faith.” Very good but very common place— The text James 4:12.— All the Protestant Churches teach this doctrine; but few of any church honestly practice upon it— I did not begin upon the Memoir of the Author— About Sunset I went up to Charles’s porch, and he and his wife passed the Evening here.
29. IV. Monday.

I went to Boston with Charles, to meet Mr Nathaniel Curtis at his request— He had written to me, for the Accounts of Petty Vaughan’s Administration on the Estates of Thomas Boylston and of Ward N. Boylston, which he thought were with me, but I could find upon search only one copy of an old account, made by Mr Curtis himself. We are both to search further for the accounts— Mr Curtis thinks he will not be ready to settle at the Norfolk County probate Office, the Account for the Executors of Ward N. Boylston, till judge Leland will hold his court at Roxbury, three weeks from to-morrow—perhaps not then— He gave me sundry papers which he had found concerning the investment of 119000 livres, proceeds of the Fair Lady’s cargo in the stock of the French loan, of 125 millions of livres made by Louis the 16th. in December 1784. among which several Letters in the French language— Papers which will make it necessary for me to prepare a Statement to the judge of probate in Suffolk County totally different from that which I had drawn up— Mr Lowell has met with a bad accident by falling over a fence and has been very ill. So that Mr Curtis has not yet settled with him. He claims 10 per cent of the amount recovered, by agreement with Mr Ward N. Boylston. I suggested to Mr Curtis the expediency of recommending to the son or one of the sons in Law of the late Moses Gill to take out Letters of Administration, upon the Estates, both of Lieutenant Governor Gill, and of his nephew, judge Willard Phillips being evidently of opinion that there must be an administration upon both to settle the Gill claim on the Boylston Estate— He approved the proposal, and said the proper person to take the Letters of Administration was Mr Cobb one of the sons in Law— Mr Curtis had a draught upon a man namedfrom R. M. Cutler of Guysborough in the Province of Nova Scotia, for Boylston Estate Lands sold there and a Letter from the man on whom the order for payment is drawn refusing payment of the same, and declaring that he is not indebted to the drawer. This is the second of Cutler’s draughts which has failed of being paid— I told Mr Cutler, I thought it would be necessary to institute a process against Cutler himself; and especially to write him a Letter signifying our surprize that he should have sent us twice successively good for nothing draughts. Mr Curtis asked me to prepare the said Letter— I met in the Street Mr George Alexander Otis and Dr. George Parkman. Mr Otis bedaubed me with flattery and whined at not having received the commendatory Letter upon his Translation of the Tusculans, which I have not yet found time to write— I asked Dr Parkman, if he had any spare copies of my remarks on certain of Shakespear’s Characters which he had published in 1835— He afterwards brought me one copy of them which he said was all he had.— After a long and blazing walk to the South end, I came out with Charles, home to dinner.— While I was absent Mr William Cost Johnson was here on a visit being upon a Summer excursion to this part of the Country. He travels with a Mrs Bruce, and her two Daughters from Virginia— Mr George Foster from Andover paid a visit of curiosity this afternoon. Charles and Abby here this Evening.
30. IV:45. Tuesday.

Morning visit from Miss Anna Thaxter, and afternoon from Isaac P. Davis and William Minot; and afterwards from Mr Loring of Hingham; who engaged me for a fishing party at Cohassett next Friday. Mr Davis left with me a New-York Courier and Enquire extra of Sunday 3. P.M. announcing the arrival of the British and American Steam Navigation Company’s new Steamer the British Queen, Lieutt. Roberts of the Royal Navy, Commander, having departed from London on the 10th. of this month, and from Portsmouth at1/2 past 12. Noon. on the 12th.— This is the third and largest of these Steam floating castles which within the last two years have abridged, by more than one half the average passage across the Atlantic. The British Queen is the largest of these Ocean Steamers measuring 1863 tons builders measure and upwards of 2000 by the custom house rule— Upon the return of the British Queen they are to launch the President of 2400 tons.— Imagination cannot conceive the result of this approximation of space upon the globe, combined with the swarming multiplication of the human species— President Van Buren and his principal competitor for the next Presidential election Henry Clay are both upon electioneering tours in the State of New-York— Van Buren associates only with his own party and has turned stump speechifier to cram down his sub-treasury system— Clay stumps it also, and tells the People, that if they are unwilling to have him for President, they must unite upon another man— Webster is in England, blowing soap bubbles; and has issued a Letter missive addressed to the People of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and stating that he withdraws his name as a Candidate for the Presidency— Mrs Charles and Elizabeth C. Adams rode to Dorchester to take tea with a friend of theirs Mrs Seaver, but came back disappointed— They and Charles who had been to Boston, and returned to dine passed the Evening here.

div.p: Copy of the Town order N. 11.

An agreement between the Selectmen of the town, William Kesey, Joseph Adams (senior) Samuel Thompson, Josiah Chaffin, and Edmund Quincy, agree to and confirm the same way to remain for the toon’s use. This way is said to pass by Peter Georges land and through the land of Henry Neal, and through the Town land two rods, and through Mr Thomas Shepard’s Land in the occupation of George Spear, and so to Mr Hough’s neck as formerly called and so through the Town Land in the antient way over Ridge Hill to Edmund Quincy’s Neck— The select men adjudge that the way at Henry Neal’s corner is so wide that one cart may pass well by another

The order of 20. May 1729. Is a vote of the town, that the way laid out by the selectmen Oct 28. 1723. through Coll. Edmund Quincys farm and the adjacent farms or Lands to the way leading from Squantum Neck in Dorchester to Milton, be continued to be a drift way for the use of the town 11/2 rod wide— Proprietors of the lands, to have liberty to hang gates for their security.
All this paper in the hand writing of Norton Quincy.
31. IV. Wednesday.
Sultry morning— Heavy Showers from Noon till Evening.

My wife was confined all the morning to her bed— I called at the Quincy Stone Bank, and made a special deposit of 630 dollars in half eagles.— Met Charles there. At the Office of the Quincy Patriot, and took one of the last Saturday’s papers in which is concluded my second Letter to the Petitioners which he has broken up into three papers. Charles and his family dined with us as usual on Wednesday’s; and I as usual did nothing but read newspapers; direct packets to be sent by the mail, and write part of a Letter to Gerrit Smith, for I could not finish it— I visited my seedling plants and observed with lingering emptiness of thought, the different processes of Nature in the act of vegetation— My nursery is now so crowded with a confused multitude of fruit and forest trees that they crush the growth of each other— It is just one month since my shagbark walnuts ceased to grow for this Season— Their leading shoots from one to two feet long have hardened into wood, and at the top of each of them is formed a bud, which will not open till next May. I have about 20 of them from two to eight years old, which are growing with favourable promise; but of all the nuts planted last fall, only four trees have come up and with little prospect that any one of them will survive the next Winter— Their growth the first Season is so exceedingly small, that the stem usually dies down to the ground the first winter— It sends up another shoot the next Spring which meets the ensuing Winter, the same fate. Sometimes this yearly stem comes five or six years succession, till a hard winter kills both stem and root.— Perhaps one in ten gets over the first winter, and then throws up a hardy flourishing stem; and the tree is secure— The Oaks fare much like the walnuts, but their growth is so irregular that it is impossible to get a straight stem for them— With the Horse chesnut, the Elm and Ash it is scarcely possible to fail—and the white Maple outgrows them all. The button wood and willow are propagated by slips, and also from self sown seeds.— I have found it all but impossible to raise cherry or plum from the Stone.— I have succeeded with a few berries of the Nettle tree, and have several of them seven years old— The tall white maple in the Seminary—one apple tree in its sixth year near the Summer house cellar, one at the centre of the Nursery in its seventh year—one fronting my chamber window, near the old Horse-chesnut and the flourishing budded cherry in the Seminary, give me hope of coming to maturity though not in my time, and by their constantly perceptibe growth afford me— The black white, red, chesnut and black jack Oaks afford som amusement; but they are so ungovernable that I scarcely notice them.— All the rest are neglected.

Day— The purpose with which I came from Washington, to devote the summer to the Memoir of my father’s life has failed; as well as half a dozen others occasionally taken up, and successively abandoned— I rise on the average at 4 in the morning— Water and sometimes weed my plants—and while the Sun rose clear went see him rise from Charles’s porch. I have written half a page of diary and am called to breakfast— Read with my two grand-daughters five chapters in the Bible. Stroll round my orchard, nursery, garden and seminary—read newspapers letters and pamphlets and despatch the Mail— Call to dinner. Another stroll Siesta— Sundown comes— Eve with my family—Bed at 10. P.M.
